member.name: T:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval
member.summary: Time intervals enumeration used by method.

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Second
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the second (i.e., starting at zero milliseconds).

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Minute
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the minute (i.e., starting at zero seconds and milliseconds).

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Hour
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the hour (i.e., starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds).

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Day
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the day (i.e., starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds).

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Month
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the month (i.e., starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds).

member.name: F:Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval.Year
member.summary: Baseline timestamp to the year (i.e., starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds).

member.name: T:Gemstone.BigEndian
member.summary: Defines a set of big-endian byte order interoperability functions.
member.remarks: This class is setup to support aggressive in-lining of big endian conversions. Bounds will not be checked as part of this function call, if bounds are violated, the exception will be thrown at the level.

startIndex is less than zero or greater than the length of value minus 1.

member.name: M:Gemstone.BitMath.GetClearedBitPositions(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Returns the bit position for every bit that is cleared in the provided value. Bit positions are defined as 0-31;

member.param: Target value for bit check enumeration.

member.name: P:Gemstone.ByteEncoding.BigEndianBinary
member.summary: Handles encoding and decoding of a byte buffer into a big-endian binary (i.e., 0 and 1's) based presentation format.
member.remarks: Although endianness is typically used in the context of byte order to handle byte order swapping), this property allows you visualize "bits" in big-endian order, right-to-left. Note that bits are normally stored in the same order as their bytes.

member.name: T:Gemstone.Common
member.summary: Defines common global functions.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Common.CreateArray``1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a strongly-typed Array.
member.param: Desired length of new array.
member.returns: New array of specified type.

remarks.para: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

The Array.CreateInstance provides better performance and more direct CLR access for array creation (not to mention less confusion on the matter of array lengths) in VB.NET, however the returned System.Array is not typed properly. This function properly casts the return array based on the type specification helping when Option Strict is enabled.

Value used to initialize all array elements.
member.returns: New array of specified type.
member.remarks: It is expected that this function will only be used in Visual Basic.NET.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Common.IIf``1(System.Boolean,``0,``0)
member.summary: Returns one of two strongly-typed objects.
member.param: The expression you want to evaluate.
Returned if expression evaluates to True.
Returned if expression evaluates to False.
member.typeparam: Return type used for immediate expression
member.returns: One of two objects, depending on the evaluation of given expression.

remarks.para: This function acts as a strongly-typed immediate if (a.k.a. inline if).

It is expected that this function will only be used in languages that do not support ?: conditional operations, e.g., Visual Basic.NET. In Visual Basic this function can be used as a strongly-typed IIf replacement by specifying "Imports gemstone.common".

member.remarks: Native types default to zero, not null, therefore this can be used to evaluate if an item is its default (i.e., uninitialized) value.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Common.IsPosixEnvironment
member.summary: Determines if the current system is a POSIX style environment.

remarks.para: Since a .NET application compiled under Mono can run under both Windows and Unix style platforms, you can use this property to easily determine the current operating environment.

This property will return true for both MacOSX and Unix environments. Use the Platform property of the to determine more specific platform type, e.g., MacOSX or Unix. Note that all flavors of Linux will show up as .

member.name: T:Gemstone.EndianOrder
member.summary: Represents an endian byte order interoperability class.
member.remarks: Intel systems use little-endian byte order, other systems, such as Unix, use big-endian byte ordering. Little-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is right-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte. Big-endian ordering means bits are ordered such that the bit whose in-memory representation is left-most is the most-significant-bit in a byte.

member.name: T:Gemstone.ISupportLifecycle
member.summary: Specifies that this object provides support for performing tasks during the key stages of object life-cycle.

member.name: E:Gemstone.ISupportLifecycle.Disposed
member.summary: Raised after the source object has been properly disposed.

member.name: P:Gemstone.ISupportLifecycle.Enabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value that indicates whether the object is enabled.
member.remarks: Typical implementation of should suspend the internal processing when the object is disabled and resume processing when the object is enabled.

member.name: M:Gemstone.ISupportLifecycle.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the state of the object.

remarks.para: Typical implementation of should allow the object state to be initialized only once. should be called automatically from one or more key entry points of the object. For example, if the object is a and it implements the interface then should be called from the method so that the object gets initialized automatically when consumed through the IDE designer surface. In addition to this should also be called from key or mandatory methods of the object, like 'Start()' or 'Connect()', so that the object gets initialized even when not consumed through the IDE designer surface.

member.name: P:Gemstone.ISupportLifecycle.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a flag that indicates whether the object has been disposed.

member.name: T:Gemstone.LibraryEvents
member.summary: Defines library-level static events.
member.remarks:
The class automatically attaches to the event so that any unobserved task exceptions encountered will be marked as observed and exposed via the event.
To disable this feature and only use custom event handling, call the method during program initialization.

member.name: M:Gemstone.LibraryEvents.DisableUnobservedTaskExceptionHandling
member.summary: Disables automatic handling of events. When disabled, any unobserved task exceptions encountered will not be marked as observed nor exposed via the event.

member.name: M:Gemstone.LibraryEvents.EnableUnobservedTaskExceptionHandling
member.summary: Enables automatic handling of events. When enabled, any unobserved task exceptions encountered are marked as observed and exposed via the event.
member.remarks: This functionality is enabled by default. This method would only ever need to be called to re-enable unobserved task exception handling after being disabled by a call to .

member.name: E:Gemstone.LibraryEvents.SuppressedException
member.summary: Exposes exceptions that were suppressed but otherwise unhandled.

remarks.para: End users should attach to this event so that suppressed exceptions can be exposed to a log.

The class automatically attaches to the event so that any unobserved task exceptions encountered will be marked as observed and exposed via the event.
To disable this feature and only use custom event handling, call the method during program initialization.
Gemstone libraries only raise this event, no library functions attach to this end user-only event.

member.name: T:Gemstone.LittleEndian
member.summary: Defines a set of little-endian byte order interoperability functions.
member.remarks: This class is setup to support aggressive in-lining of little endian conversions. Bounds will not be checked as part of this function call, if bounds are violated, the exception will be thrown at the level.

member.name: T:Gemstone.NtpTimeTag
member.summary: Represents a standard Network Time Protocol (NTP) time-tag.
member.remarks: As recommended by RFC-2030, all NTP timestamps earlier than 3h 14m 08s UTC on 20 January 1968 are reckoned from 6h 28m 16s UTC on 7 February 2036. This gives the class a functioning range of 1968-01-20 03:14:08 to 2104-02-26 09:42:23.

member.name: T:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer
member.summary: Represents a high-resolution timer and timestamp class.
member.remarks: For Windows deployments, implementation is based on the Windows multimedia timer. For other deployments, e.g., POSIX, implementation uses a basic timer for compatibility - this should have ~10ms of resolution when used on standard Linux systems.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the should raise the event each time the specified period elapses or only after the first time it elapses.
member.returns: truetrue if the should raise the event each time the interval elapses; false if it should raise the event only once after the first time the interval elapses. The default is true.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer.Capabilities
member.summary: Gets the system multimedia timer capabilities.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer.ClearMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears a previously set minimum timer resolution established using .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the function.

remarks.para: Call this function immediately after you are finished using the . You must match each call to with a call to , specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple SetMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution.
This method is currently ignored under Mono deployments.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the is running.

member.summary: Gets or sets the time between events, in milliseconds.
member.exception: If the timer has already been disposed.

member.name: P:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer.Resolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the resolution, in milliseconds.

remarks.para: The resolution is in milliseconds. The resolution increases with smaller values; a resolution of 0 indicates periodic events should occur with the greatest possible accuracy. To reduce system overhead, however, you should use the maximum value appropriate for your application.
This property is currently ignored under Mono deployments.

member.exception: If the timer has already been disposed.

member.name: M:Gemstone.PrecisionTimer.SetMinimumTimerResolution(System.Int32)
member.summary: Requests a minimum resolution for periodic timers such as the .
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application. A lower value specifies a higher (more accurate) resolution.

remarks.para: Call this function immediately before using the and call immediately after you are finished using the PrecisionTimer. You must match each call to with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple ClearMinimumTimerResolution calls as long as each call is matched with a call to ClearMinimumTimerResolution. This function affects a global Windows setting. Windows uses the lowest value (that is, highest resolution) requested by any process. Setting a higher resolution can improve the accuracy of time-out intervals in wait functions. However, it can also reduce overall system performance, because the thread scheduler switches tasks more often. High resolutions can also prevent the CPU power management system from entering power-saving modes. See timeBeginPeriod Windows API for more information.
This method is currently ignored under Mono deployments.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Serialization.GetOrDefault``1(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.String,``0)
member.summary: Gets value for specified ; otherwise .
member.param: object that contains deserialized values.
Name of deserialized parameter to retrieve.
Default value to return if does not exist or cannot be deserialized.
member.typeparam: Type of parameter to get from .
member.returns: Value for specified ; otherwise
member.remarks: do not have a direct way of determining if an item with a specified name exists, so when calling one of the Get(n) functions you will simply get a if the parameter does not exist; similarly you will receive this exception if the parameter fails to properly deserialize. This extension method protects against both of these failures and returns a default value if the named parameter does not exist or cannot be deserialized.

member.name: T:Gemstone.ShortTime
member.summary: Represents a high resolution time that is very granular but may drift if trying to accurately measure long time durations (Such as hours). This time is not adjusted with changes to the system clock. Typical clock drifts by about 2-3 ms per minute as apposed to 0.4ms per minute for standard .
member.remarks: Call times are about 40+ million calls per second.

member.name: T:Gemstone.Ticks
member.summary: Represents an instant in time, or time period, as a 64-bit signed integer with a value that is expressed as the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.

remarks.para: can represent an "instant in time" and therefore can be used exactly like a . The difference between and is that is essentially a long integer (i.e., an ) which represents the number of ticks that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001 with each tick having a resolution of 100-nanoseconds. You would use in places where you needed to directly represent time in high-resolution, i.e., time with sub-second accuracy, using an object that will act like a long integer but handle time conversions. can also represent a "time period" (e.g., the number of ticks elapsed since a process started) and thus can also be used like a ; when used in this manner the method can be used to convert the value into a handy textual representation of elapsed years, days, hours, minutes and seconds or sub-seconds.

This class behaves just like an representing a time in ticks; it is implicitly castable to and from an and therefore can be generally used "as" an Int64 directly. It is also implicitly castable to and from a , a , an and a .

member.summary: Returns a floor-aligned microsecond distribution timestamp for given .

member.name: M:Gemstone.Ticks.AlignToSubsecondDistribution(Gemstone.Ticks,System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Returns a floor-aligned sub-second distribution timestamp for given .
member.param: Timestamp to align.
Samples per second to use for distribution.
Defines the time resolution to use when aligning to its proper distribution timestamp.
member.returns: A floor-aligned sub-second distribution timestamp for given .
member.remarks:
Time resolution value is typically a power of 10 based on the number of ticks per the desired resolution. The following table defines common resolutions and their respective values: ResolutionTime Resolution Value
Seconds
Milliseconds
Microseconds
Ticks0 If source timestamps have variation, i.e., they are not aligned within common distributions, the can be adjusted to include slack to accommodate the variance. When including slack in the time resolution, the value will depend on the , for example: you could use 330,000 for 30 samples per second, 160,000 for 60 samples per second, and 80,000 for 120 samples per second. Actual slack value may need to be more or less depending on the size of the source timestamp variation.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Ticks.BaselinedTimestamp(Gemstone.BaselineTimeInterval)
member.summary: Creates a new value that represents a base-lined timestamp, in 100-nanoseconds intervals, that begins at the beginning of the specified time interval.
member.param: to which timestamp should be base-lined.
member.returns: A new value that represents a base-lined timestamp, in 100-nanoseconds intervals, that begins at the specified .
member.remarks:
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at zero milliseconds.
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at zero seconds and milliseconds.
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Base-lining to the would return the value starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.

member.summary: Determines if time, represented by value in local time, is valid by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.

member.summary: Returns a copy of the specified portion of the array.

Offset into array.
Length of array to copy at offset.
member.returns: A array of data copied from the specified portion of the source array.

remarks.para: Returned array will be extended as needed to make it the specified , but it will never be less than the source array length - .

If an existing array of primitives is already available, using the directly instead of this extension method may be optimal since this method always allocates a new return array. Unlike , however, this function also works with non-primitive types.

member.name: M:Gemstone.ArrayExtensions.ArrayExtensions.CompareTo``1(``0[],``0[])
member.summary: Returns comparison results of two binary arrays.
member.param: Source array.
Other array to compare to array.

returns.para: A signed integer that indicates the relative comparison of array and array.

item.description: Source array is less than other array.
Source array is equal to other array.
Source array is greater than other array.

member.remarks: Note that if both arrays are null the arrays will be considered equal. If one array is null and the other array is not null, the non-null array will be considered larger. If the array lengths are not equal, the array with the larger length will be considered larger. If the array lengths are equal, the arrays will be compared based on content.

member.name: T:Gemstone.BitExtensions.BitExtensions

member.name: M:Gemstone.BitExtensions.BitExtensions.BitRotL(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs rightwise bit-rotation for the specified number of rotations.
member.param: Value used for bit-rotation.
Number of rotations to perform.
member.returns: Value that has its bits rotated to the right the specified number of times.
member.remarks: Actual rotation direction is from a big-endian perspective - this is an artifact of the native .NET bit shift operators. As a result bits may actually appear to rotate right on little-endian architectures.

member.remarks: Actual rotation direction is from a big-endian perspective - this is an artifact of the native .NET bit shift operators. As a result bits may actually appear to rotate left on little-endian architectures.

member.name: M:Gemstone.CharExtensions.CharExtensions.IsWordTerminator(System.Char)
member.summary: Tests a character to determine if it marks the end of a typical English word.
member.param: Input character to check.
member.returns: true if character is a work separator.
member.remarks:
Performs no testing for ASCII codes > 127.
Does not separate words based on punctuation of ' % - _
However does include the angle bracket symbols < > as separators
For reference the standard char tests are:
"IsSperator (1) == simple space (32 or 160) only.
IsPunctuation (23) == . , ! ? : ; " ' [ ] { } ( ) \ / @ % # * & - _ (plus other char's > 127)
IsSymbol (8) == $ + < > = ^ ` ~
IsWhiteSpace (6) == control char's 9 thru 13, plus 32 -- TAB, LF, VT, FF, CR, SP

member.name: T:Gemstone.Collections.ListCollection`1
member.summary: A faster and functionally equivalent implementation of
member.typeparam: The type of the element in the collection

remarks.para: is based upon an . This means any simple call to the class is a function call that cannot be in-lined. This implementation forces the underlying item to be and shadows many of the methods to call instead of .
Since this class references the same underlying object, it can be successfully implemented as a or casted it its underlying type .

Profiling this class yield a ForEach loop and For loop that executes between 2-4 times faster than . This depends on the number of items in the list. The fewer the faster. Other operations such as Add/Insert/Remove are closer to 50% faster. Count is now in-lined (~20 times faster).
This performance is negated if accessing this class via the IList interface. When possible, use only strongly typed names.

member.name: T:Gemstone.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.InitialValueScriptAttribute
member.summary: Defines an attribute that will define an initial value script for a modeled table field that will get evaluated and assigned in the target use environment, e.g., Javascript.

remarks.para: Example to set initial value to 30 days from now using a Javascript expression: [InitialValueScript("(new Date()).addDays(30)")]

Note that the should be used to set any constant values for new modeled record instances and the gemstone.expressions.model.DefaultValueExpressionAttribute should be used for applying any needed server-side run-time expression defaults, either of these will get assigned when using the gemstone.data.model.TableOperations<T>.NewRecord function. The is used to initialize the property value using an expression that gets evaluated in the target environment.

member.remarks: Expression should be in target language, e.g., Javascript.

member.param: Timestamp to baseline.
to which should be baselined.
member.returns: A new value that represents a baselined timestamp that begins at the specified .
member.remarks:
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.
Baselining to the would return the value starting at month one, day one, zero hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds.

member.summary: Determines if the specified local time is valid, by comparing it to the system clock.
member.param: Time to test for validity.
The allowed lag time, in seconds, before assuming time is too old to be valid.
The allowed lead time, in seconds, before assuming time is too advanced to be valid.
member.returns: True, if time is within the specified range.

remarks.para: Time is considered valid if it exists within the specified lag time/lead time range of current time.
Note that lag time and lead time must be greater than zero, but can be set to sub-second intervals.

member.name: T:Gemstone.IO.BlockAllocatedMemoryStream
member.summary: Defines a stream whose backing store is memory. Externally this class operates similar to a , internally it uses dynamically allocated buffer blocks instead of one large contiguous array of data.

remarks.para: The has two primary benefits over a normal , first, the allocation of a large contiguous array of data in can fail when the requested amount of contiguous memory is unavailable - the prevents this; second, a will constantly reallocate the buffer size as the stream grows and shrinks and then copy all the data from the old buffer to the new - the maintains its blocks over its life cycle, unless manually cleared, thus eliminating unnecessary allocations and garbage collections when growing and reusing a stream.

Important: Unlike , the will not use a user provided buffer as its backing buffer. Any user provided buffers used to instantiate the class will be copied into internally managed reusable memory buffers. Subsequently, the does not support the notion of a non-expandable stream. If you are using a with your own buffer, the will not provide any immediate benefit.
Note that the will maintain all allocated blocks for stream use until the method is called or the class is disposed.
No members in the are guaranteed to be thread safe. Make sure any calls are synchronized when simultaneously accessed from different threads.

member.remarks: Unlike , the will not use the provided as its backing buffer. The buffer will be copied into internally managed reusable memory buffers. Subsequently, the notion of a non-expandable stream is not supported.
member.exception: is null.

member.name: M:Gemstone.IO.FilePath.GetDirectoryName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the directory information from the specified file path.
member.param: The file path from which the directory information is to be obtained.
member.returns: Directory information.
member.remarks: This differs from in that it will see if last name in path is a directory and, if it exists, will properly treat that part of path as a directory. The .NET path function always assumes last entry is a file name if path is not suffixed with a slash. For example: Path.GetDirectoryName(@"C:\Music") will return "C:\", however, FilePath.GetDirectoryName(@"C:\Music") will return "C:\Music\", so long as Music directory exists.

remarks.para: The intent of this function is to provide a sane method for opening a file which may produce errors due to read/write contention. Usage of this class is fairly simple using the static methods built into the class.
This method will only retry if an occurs while executing the . After retrying for at least seconds, this function will throw the last IOException it encountered.

member.name: M:Gemstone.IO.FilePath.GetUniqueFilePath(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique file path for the given file by checking for name collisions and adding a sequence number to the end of the file name if there is a collision.
member.param: The path to the original file before adding the sequence number.
member.returns: The unique path to the file.
member.remarks:
This method is designed to handle the case where the user wishes to create a file in a folder with a given name when there is a possibility that the name is already taken. Using this method, it is possible to create files with names in the following format:
File.ext
File (1).ext
File (2).ext
...
This method uses a linear search to find a unique file name, so it is suitable for situations where there are a small number of collisions for each file name. This will detect and fill gaps that can occur when files are deleted (for instance, if "File (1).ext" were deleted from the list above).

member.name: M:Gemstone.IO.FilePath.GetUniqueFilePathWithBinarySearch(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a unique file path for the given file by checking for name collisions and adding a sequence number to the end of the file name if there is a collision.
member.param: The path to the original file before adding the sequence number.
member.returns: The unique path to the file.
member.remarks:
This method is designed to handle the case where the user wishes to create a file in a folder with a given name when there is a possibility that the name is already taken. Using this method, it is possible to create files with names in the following format:
File.ext
File (1).ext
File (2).ext
...
This method uses a binary search to find a unique file name, so it is suitable for situations where a large number of files will be created with the same file name, and the next unique file name needs to be found relatively quickly. It will not always detect gaps in the sequence numbers that can occur when files are deleted (for instance, if "File (1).ext" were deleted from the list above).

member.name: M:Gemstone.IO.FilePath.IsFilePatternMatch(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified file name matches the given file spec (wild-cards are defined as '*' or '?' characters).
member.param: The file spec used for matching the specified file name.
The file path to be tested against the specified file spec for a match.
true to specify a case-insensitive match; otherwise false.
member.returns: true if the specified file name matches the given file spec; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
The syntax for adheres to the following rules:
Either '\' or '/' (as defined by and ) can match the other.
A single '\' or '/' at the beginning of the pattern matches any valid path root (such as "C:\" or "\\server\share").
A '?' matches a single character which would be valid in a file name (as defined by ).
A '*' matches any number of characters which would be valid in a file name.
A sequence of "**\" or "**/" matches any number of sequential directories.
Any other character matches itself.
member.exception: contains one or more of the invalid characters defined in .

true to specify a case-insensitive match; otherwise false.
member.returns: true if the specified file name matches any of the given file specs; otherwise false.
member.remarks:
The syntax for adheres to the following rules:
Either '\' or '/' (as defined by and ) can match the other.
A single '\' or '/' at the beginning of the pattern matches any valid path root (such as "C:\" or "\\server\share").
A '?' matches a single character which would be valid in a file name (as defined by ).
A '*' matches any number of characters which would be valid in a file name.

member.name: M:Gemstone.IO.Parsing.BinaryImageParserBase.ParseFrame(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Protocol specific frame parsing algorithm.
member.param: Buffer containing data to parse.
Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The length of the data that was parsed.

remarks.para: Implementers can choose to focus on parsing a single frame in the buffer even if there are other frames available in the buffer. Base class will continue to move through buffer on behalf of derived class until all the buffer has been processed. Just return the total amount of data was parsed and the remaining unparsed will be prepended to next received buffer.

Derived implementations should return an integer value that represents the length of the data that was parsed, and zero if not enough data was able to be parsed. Note that exceptions are expensive when parsing fast moving streaming data and a good coding practice for implementations of this method will be to not throw an exception when there is not enough data to parse the data, instead check the property to verify there is enough buffer data to represent the desired image. If there is not enough data to represent the image return zero and base class will prepend buffer onto next incoming set of data.

Because of the expense incurred when an exception is thrown, any exceptions encountered in the derived implementations of this method will cause the current data buffer to be discarded and a event to be raised. Doing this prevents exceptions from being thrown repeatedly for the same data. If your code implementation recognizes a malformed image, you can raise a custom event to indicate this instead of throwing as exception and keep moving through the buffer as an optimization.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Reflection.AssemblyExtensions.AssemblyExtensions.TryLoadAllReferences(System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Recursively attempts to load all assemblies referenced from the given assembly.
member.param: The assembly whose references are to be loaded.
member.returns: true if the references were successfully loaded; false otherwise.
member.remarks: If an object is created from a type that is loaded from an assembly, and if that assembly's references fail to load during instantiation, an exception may be thrown from both the constructor and the finalizer of the object that was instantiated. This method allows us to ensure that all referenced assemblies can be loaded before attempting to instantiate a type from that assembly.

member.name: T:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart
member.summary: Indicates the date/time element that a represents.
member.remarks: This enumeration specifically corresponds to the UNIX crontab date/time elements.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart.Minute
member.summary: represents minutes. Legal values are 0 through 59, or 60 which maps to 0.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart.Hour
member.summary: represents hours. Legal values are 0 through 23, or 24 which maps to 0.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart.Day
member.summary: represents day of month. Legal values are 1 through 31.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart.Month
member.summary: represents months. Legal values are 1 through 12.

member.name: F:Gemstone.Scheduling.DateTimePart.DayOfWeek
member.summary: represents day of week. Legal values are 0 through 6, or 7 which maps to 0. Sunday is 0 and Saturday is 6.

member.name: T:Gemstone.Scheduling.Schedule
member.summary: Represents a schedule defined using UNIX crontab syntax.

remarks.para: Operators:

There are several ways of specifying multiple date/time values in a field:
The comma (',') operator specifies a list of values, for example: "1,3,4,7,8"
The dash ('-') operator specifies a range of values, for example: "1-6", which is equivalent to "1,2,3,4,5,6"
The asterisk ('*') operator specifies all possible values for a field. For example, an asterisk in the hour time field would be equivalent to 'every hour' (subject to matching other specified fields).
The slash ('/') operator (called "step"), which can be used to skip a given number of values. For example, "*/3" in the hour time field is equivalent to "0,3,6,9,12,15,18,21". So "*" specifies 'every hour' but the "*/3" means only those hours divisible by 3.
Fields:
Each of the patterns from the first five fields may be either * (an asterisk), which matches all legal values, or a list of elements separated by commas.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cron for more information.

member.name: M:Gemstone.StringExtensions.StringExtensions.ParseKeyValuePairs(System.String,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Char,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Parses key/value pair expressions from a string. Parameter pairs are delimited by and multiple pairs separated by . Supports encapsulated nested expressions.
member.param: String containing key/value pair expressions to parse.
Character that delimits one key/value pair from another.
Character that delimits key from value.
Optional character that marks the start of a value such that value could contain other or characters.
Optional character that marks the end of a value such that value could contain other or characters.
Flag determines whether duplicates are ignored. If flag is set to false an will be thrown when all key parameters are not unique.
member.returns: Dictionary of key/value pairs.

remarks.para: Parses a string containing key/value pair expressions (e.g., "localPort=5001; transportProtocol=UDP; interface=0.0.0.0"). This method treats all "keys" as case-insensitive. Nesting of key/value pair expressions is allowed by encapsulating the value using the and values (e.g., "dataChannel={Port=-1;Clients=localhost:8800}; commandChannel={Port=8900}; dataFormat=FloatingPoint;"). There must be one for each encountered in the value or a will be thrown. Multiple levels of nesting is supported. If the flag is set to false an will be thrown when all key parameters are not unique. Note that keys within nested expressions are considered separate key/value pair strings and are not considered when checking for duplicate keys.

member.exception: value is null.
All delimiters must be unique -or- all keys must be unique when is set to false.
Total nested key/value pair expressions are mismatched -or- encountered before .

member.summary: Converts total into a textual representation of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds with the specified number of fractional digits given string array of time names.
member.param: Seconds to convert to elapsed time.
Number of fractional digits to display for seconds.
Time names array to use during textual conversion.
Minimum sub-second resolution to display. Defaults to .
member.returns: The string representation of the value of this instance, consisting of the number of years, days, hours, minutes and seconds represented by this value.

array needs one string entry for each of the following names:
" year", " years", " day", " days", " hour", " hours", " minute", " minutes", " second", " seconds", "less than ".

member.name: M:Gemstone.Units.Volume.TryParse(System.String,Gemstone.Units.Volume@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a number to its equivalent. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.
member.param: A string containing a number to convert.

When this method returns, contains the value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not of the correct format, or represents a number less than or greater than . This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

When this method returns, contains the value equivalent to the number contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or zero if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null, is not in a format compliant with style, or represents a number less than or greater than . This parameter is passed uninitialized.
A object that supplies culture-specific formatting information about s.
member.returns: true if s was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Gemstone.WordExtensions.WordExtensions.HighByte(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Returns the high-byte from an unsigned word (UInt16).
member.param: 2-byte, 16-bit unsigned integer value.
member.returns: The high-order byte of the specified 16-bit unsigned integer value.
member.remarks: On little-endian architectures (e.g., Intel platforms), this will be the byte value whose in-memory representation is the same as the right-most, most-significant-byte of the integer value.
